Thrice blessed man that lost her whilst she was good,
Fair, young, unblemished, constant, loving, chaste.
I tell thee youth, age knows, young loves seem graced,
Which with grey cares, rude jars, are oft defaced.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But she was full of hope.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: May be, may be: but that, which may be, stood,
Stands now without all may; she died good,
And dost thou grieve?

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: I ha' lost a true friend.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I live encompassed with two blessed souls.
Thou lost a good wife, thou lost a true friend, ha?
Two of the rarest lendings of the heavens:
But lendings: which at the fixed day of pay
Set down by fate, thou must restore again.
O what unconscionable souls are here?
Are you all like the spoke-shaves of the church?
Have you no maw to restitution?
Hast lost a true friend, coz? than thou hadst one.
I tell thee youth, 'tis all as difficult
To find true friend in this apostate age
(That balks all right affiance twixt two hearts)
As 'tis to find a fixed modest heart,
Under a painted breast. Lost a true friend?
O happy soul that lost him whilst he was true.
Believe it coz, I to my tears have found,
Oft durts respect makes firmer friends unsound.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: You have lost a good son.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why there's the comfort on't, that he was good:
Alas, poor innocent.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Why weeps mine uncle?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ha, dost ask me why? ha? ha?
Good coz, look here.
sp.stage: He shows him his son's breast.
sp.l: Man will break out, despite philosophy.
Why, all this while I ha' but played a part,
Like to some boy, that acts a tragedy,
Speaks burly words, and raves out passion:
But, when he thinks upon his infant weakness,
He droops his eye. I spoke more than a god;
Yet am less than a man.
I am the miserablest soul that breathes.

div.stage: Antonio starts up.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Slid, sir ye lie: by th'heart of grief, thou liest.
I scorn't that any wretched should survive,
Outmounting me in that superlative,
Most miserable, most unmatched in woe:
Who dare assume that, but Antonio?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Will't still be so? and shall you bloodhound live?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Have I an arm, a heart, a sword, a soul?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Were you but private unto what we know

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I'll know it all; first let's inter the dead:
Let's dig his grave, with that shall dig the heart,
Liver, and entrails of the murderer.

div.stage: They strike the stage with their daggers, and the grave openeth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wilt sing a dirge boy?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No, no song: 'twill be vile out of tune.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Indeed he's hoarse: the poor boy's voice is cracked.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Why coz? why should it not be hoarse and cracked,
When all the strings of nature's symphony
Are cracked, and jar? why should his voice keep tune,
When there's no music in the breast of man?
I'll say an honest antic rhyme I have;
(Help me good sorrow-mates to give him grave.)
sp.stage: They all help to carry Feliche to his grave.
sp.l: Death, exile, plaints, and woe,
Are but man's lackeys, not his foe.
No mortal scapes from fortune's war,
Without a wound, at least a scar.
Many have led these to the grave:
But all shall follow, none shall save.
Blood of my youth, rot and consume,
Virtue, in dirt, doth life assume:
With this old saw, close up this dust;
Thrice blessed man that dyeth just.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: The gloomy wing of night begins to stretch
His lazy pinion over all the air:
We must be stiff and steady in resolve.
Let's thus our hands, our hearts, our arms involve.

div.stage: They wreathe their arms.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now swear we by this Gordian knot of love,
By the fresh turned up mould that wraps my son;
By the dead brow of triple Hecate:
Ere night shall close the lids of you bright stars,
we'll sit as heavy on Piero's heart,
As Aetna doth on groaning Pelorus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thanks good old man.
We'll cast at royal chance.
Let's think a plot; then pell-mell vengeance.

div.stage: Exeunt, their arms wreathed.
¶ The cornets sound for the act.
¶ The dumb show.

div.head: Scen. i.
div.stage: ¶ Enter at one door, Castilio and Forobosco, with halberts: four pages with torches: luceo bare: Piero, Maria and Alberto, talking: Alberto draws out his dagger, Maria her knife, aiming to menace the Duke. Then Galeatzo betwixt two senators, reading a paper to them: at which, they all make semblance of loathing Piero, and knit their fists at him; two ladies and nutriche: all these go softly over the stage, whilst at the other door enters the ghost of Andrugio, who passeth by them, tossing his torch about his head in triumph. All forsake the stage, saving Andrugio, who speaking, begins the act.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Venit dies, tempúsque, quo reddat suis
Animam squallentem sceleribus.
The fist of strenuous vengeance is clutched,
And stern Vindicta towereth up aloft,
That she may fall with a more weighty poise,
And crush lives sap from out Piero's veins.
Now begins the leprous cores of ulcered sins
Wheal to a head: now is his fate grown mellow,
Instant to fall into the rotten jaws
Of chap-fallen death. Now down looks providence,
T'attend the last act of my son's revenge.
Be gracious, observation, to our scene:
For now the plot unites his scattered limbs
Close in contracted bands. The Florence prince
(Drawn by firm notice of the Duke's black deeds)
Is made a partner in conspiracy.
The states of Venice are so swollen in hate
Against the Duke, for his accursed deeds
(Of which they are confirmed by some odd letters
Found in dead Strotzo's study, which had passed
Betwixt Piero and the murdering slave)
That they can scarce retain from bursting forth
In plain revolt. O, now triumphs my ghost;
Exclaiming, heaven's just; for I shall see,
The scourge of murder and impiety.Exit

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Balurdo from under the stage.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p:
Ho, who's above there, ho? A murrain on all proverbs. They say, hunger breaks through stone walls; but I am as gaunt, as lean ribbed famine: yet I can burst through no stone walls. O, now sir Geoffrey, show thy valour, break prison, and be
hanged. Nor shall the darkest nook of hell contain the discontented sir Balurdo's ghost. Well, I am out well, I have put off the prison to put on the rope. O poor shotten herring, what a pickle art thou in! O hunger, how thou domineer'st in my guts! O, for a fat leg of ewe mutton in stewed broth; or drunken song to feed on. I could belch rarely, for I am all wind. Oh cold, cold, cold, cold, cold. O poor knight, o poor sir Geoffrey; sing like an unicorn, before thou dost dip thy horn in the water of death; o cold, o sing, o cold, o poor sir Geoffrey, sing, sing.

div.stage: Cantat.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: ¶ Enter Antonio and Alberto, at several doors, their rapiers drawn, in their masking attire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Vindicta.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Mellida.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Alberto.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hath the Duke supped?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yes, and triumphant revels mount aloft.
The Duke drinks deep to overdowe his grief.
The court is racked to pleasure, each man strains
To feign a jocund eye. The Florentine

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Young Galeatzo?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Even he is mighty on our part. The states of Venice

div.stage: ¶ Enter Pandulpho running, in masking attire.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Like high-swollen floods, drive down the muddy dams
Of pent allegiance. O, my lusty bloods,
Heaven sits clapping of our enterprise.
I have been labouring general favour firm,
And I do find the citizens grown sick
With swallowing the bloody crudities
Of black Piero's acts; they fain would cast
And vomit him from off their government.
Now is the plot of mischief ripped wide ope:
Letters are found twixt Strotzo and the Duke,
So clear apparent: yet more firmly strong
By suiting circumstance; that as I walked
Muffled, to eves-drop speech, I might observe
The graver statesmen whispering fearfully.
Here one gives nods and hums, what he would speak:
The rumour's got among troop of citizens,
Making loud murmur, with confused din:
One shakes his head, and sighs; oh ill used power:
Another frets, and sets his grinding teeth,
Foaming with rage; and swears this must not be.
Here one complots, and on a sudden starts,
And cries; o monstrous, o deep villainy!
All knit there nerves, and from beneath swollen brows
Appears a gloating eye of much mislike:
Whilst swart Piero's lips reek steam of wine,
swallows lust-thoughts, devours all pleasing hopes,
With strong imagination of, what not?
O, now Vindicta; that's the word we have:
A royal vengeance, or a royal grave.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Vindicta.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I am acold.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Who's there? sir Geoffrey?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: A poor knight, god wot: the nose of thy knighthood is bitten off with cold. O poor sir Geoffrey, cold, cold.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What chance of fortune hath tripped up his heels,
And laid him in the kennel? ha?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I will discourse it all. Poor honest soul,
Hadst thou a beaver to clasp up thy face,
Thou shouldst associate us in maskery,
And see revenge.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Nay, and you talk of revenge, my stomach's up,
sp.p: For I am most tyrannically hungry. A beaver? I have a headpiece, a skull, a brain of proof, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Slink to my chamber then, and tire thee.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Is there a fire?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Is there a fat leg of ewe mutton?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: And a clean shirt?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Then am I for you, most pathetically, and unvulgarly, law.Exit

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Resolved hearts, time curtals night, opportunity shakes us his foretop. Steel your thoughts, sharp your resolve, embolden your spirit, grasp your swords; alarum mischief, and with an undaunted brow, out scout the grim opposition
of most menacing peril.
sp.l: Hark here, proud pomp shoots mounting triumph up,
Born in loud accents to the front of Jove.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O now, he that wants soul to kill a slave,
Let him die slave, and rot in peasants' grave.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, and thine, most noble heart,
Thus will we live, and, but thus, never part.

div.stage: Exeunt twined together.
¶ Cornets sound a sennet.

div.head: Scaena qvarta.
div.stage: ¶ Enter Castilio and Forobosco, two pages with torches, Lucio bore, Piero and Maria, Galeatzo, two senators and nutriche.
¶ Piero to Maria.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Sit close unto my breast, heart of my love,
Advance thy drooping eyes,
Thy son is drowned,
Rich happiness that such a son is drowned.
Thy husband's dead, life of my joys most blessed,
In that the sapless log, that pressed thy bed
With an unpleasing weight, being lifted hence,
Even I Piero, live to warm his place.
I tell you, lady, had you viewed us both,
With an unpartiall eye, when first we wooed
Your maiden beauties, I had born the prize,
'tis firm I had: for, fair, I ha' done that

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Murder.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Which he would quake to have adventured;
Thou knowest I have.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Murdered my husband.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Born out the shock of war, and done, what not,
That valour durst. Dost love me fairest? say.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As I do hate my son, I love thy soul.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Why then Io to Hymen, mount a lofty note:
Fill red cheeked Bacchus, let Lyeus float
In burnished goblets. Force the plump lipped god,
Skip light lavoltas in your full sapped veins.
'Tis well brim full. Even I have glut of blood:
Let quaff carouse; I drink this Bordeaux wine
Unto the health of dead Andrugio,
Feliche, Strotzo ▪ and Antonio's ghosts.
Would I had some poison to infuse it with;
That having done this honour to the dead,
I might send one to give them notice on't.
I would endear my favour to the full.
Boy, sing aloud, make heaven's vault to ring
With thy breath's strength. I drink. Now loudly sing.

div.stage: Cantat.
¶ The song ended, the cornets sound a sennet.

div.head: Scaena qvinta.
div.stage: ¶ Enter Antonio, Pandulfo, and Alberto, in maskery, Balurdo, and a torchbearer.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Call Julio hither; where's the little fowl?
I saw him not today. Here's sport alone
For him, i'faith; for babes and fools, I know,
Relish not substance, but applaud the show.

div.stage: To the conspirators as they stand in rank for the measure.
To Antonio.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: All blessed fortune crown your brave attempt.
I have a troop to second your attempt.
The Venice states join hearts unto your hands.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: By the delights in contemplation
Of coming joys, 'tis magnificent.
You grace my marriage eve with sumptuous pomp.
Sound still, loud music. O, your breath gives grace
To curious feet, that in proud measure pace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mother, is Julio's body

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Speak not, doubt not; all is above all hope.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then will I dance and whirl about the air.
Methinks I am all soul, all heart, all spirit.
Now murder shall receive his ample merit.

div.stage: ¶ The measure.
¶ While the measure is dancing, Andrugio's ghost is placed betwixt the music houses.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Bring hither suckets, candied delicates.
We'll taste some sweet meats, gallants, ere we sleep.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We'll Cook your sweet meats, gallants, with tart sour sauce.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Here will I sit, spectator of revenge,
And glad my ghost in anguish of my foe.

div.stage: The maskers whisper with Piero.

sp.speaker: Piero.
sp.l: Marry and shall; i'faith I were too rude,
If I gainsaid so civil fashion.
The maskers pray you to forbear the room,
Till they have banqueted. Let it be so:
No man presume to visit them, on death.
Only myself? O, why with all my heart ▪
I'll fill your consort; here Piero sits:
Come on, unmask, let's fall to

div.stage: The conspirators bind Piero, pluck out his tongue, and triumph over him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Murder and torture: no prayers, no entreaties.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: We'll spoil your oratory. Out with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have't Pandulpho: the veins panting bleed,
Trickling fresh gore about my fist. Bind fast; so, so.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Blessed be thy hand. I taste the joys of heaven,
Viewing my son triumph in his black blood.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Down to the dungeon with him, I'll dungeon with him; I'll fool you: sir Geoffrey will be sir Geoffrey. I'll tickle you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Behold, black dog.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Grinst thou, thou snurling cur?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Eat thy black liver.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To thine anguish see
a fool triumphant in thy misery.
Vex him Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He weeps: now do I glorify my hands,
I had no vengeance, if I had no tears.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fall to, good Duke. O these are worthless cares,
You have no stomach to them; look, look here:
Here lies a dish to feast thy father's gorge.
Here's flesh and blood, which I am sure thou lovest.

div.stage: ¶ Piero seems to condole his son

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Was he thy flesh, thy son, thy dearest son?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So was Andrugio my dearest father.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: So was Feliche my dearest son.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Maria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: So was Andrugio my dearest husband.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My father found no pity in thy blood.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Remorse was banished, when thou slewest my son.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: When thou empoisoned'st my loving lord,
Exiled was piety.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now, therefore, pity, piety, remorse,
Be aliens to our thoughts: grim fire-eyed rage
Possess us wholly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thy son? true: and which is my most joy,
I hope no bastard, but thy very blood
Thy true begotten, most legitimate
And loved issue: there's the comfort on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Scum of the mud of hell.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Slime of all filth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou most detested road.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Thou most retort and obtuse rascal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus charge we death at thee: remember hell,
And let the howling murmurs of black spirits,
the horrid torments of the damned ghosts
Affright thy soul, as it descendeth down
Into the entrails of the ugly deep.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sa, sa; no, let him die, and die, and still be dying,
sp.stage: ¶ They offer to run all at Piero, and on a sudden stop.
sp.l: And yet not die, till he hath died and died
Ten thousand deaths in agony of heart.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now pell-mell ; thus the hand of heaven chokes
The throat of murder. This for my father's blood.

div.stage: He stabs Piero.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: This for my son.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This for them all.
And this, and this; sink to the heart of hell.

div.stage: They run all at Piero with their rapiers.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Murder for murder, blood for blood doth yell.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: 'Tis done, and now my soul shall sleep in rest.
Sons that revenge their father's blood, are blessed.

div.stage: The curtains being drawn, exit Andrugio.

div.head: Scaena sexta.
div.stage: ¶ Enter Galeatzo, two senators, luceo, Forobosco, Castilio, and ladies.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.p: Whose hand presents this gory spectacle?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Mine.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No: mine.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: No: mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not lose the glory of the deed,
Were all the tortures of the deepest hell
Fixed to my limbs. I pierced the monster's heart,
With an undaunted hand.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: By yond bright spangled front of heaven 'twas I:
'Twas I sluiced out his life blood.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Tush, to say truth, 'twas all.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: Blessed be you all, and may your honours live
Religiously held sacred, even for ever and ever.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: To Antonio. Thou art another Hercules to us,
In ridding huge pollution from our state.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: Antonio, belief is fortified,
With most invincible approvements of much wrong,
By this Piero to thee. We have found
Beadroles of mischief, plots of villainy,
Laid twixt the Duke and Strotzo: which we found
Too firmly acted.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.p: Alas poor orphan.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Poor? standing triumphant over Belzebub?
Having large interest for blood; and yet deemed poor?

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: What satisfaction outward pomp can yield,
Or chiefest fortunes of the Venice state,
Claim freely. You are well seasoned props,
And will not warp, or lean to either part ▪
Calamity gives man a steady heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are amazed at your benignity:
But other vows constrain another course.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: We know the world, and did we know no more,
We would not live to know: but since constraint
Of holy bands forceth us keep this lodge
of dirt's corruption, till dread power calls
Our soul's appearance, we will live enclosed
In holy verge of some religious order,
Most constant votaries.

div.stage: The curtains are drawn, Piero departeth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: First let's cleanse our hands,
Purge hearts of hatred, and entomb my love:
Over whose hearse, I'll weep away my brain
In true affections tears,
For her sake, here I vow a virgin bed.
She lives in me, with her my love is dead.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: We will attend her mournful exequies,
Conduct you to your calm sequestered life,
And then

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Leave us, to meditate on misery;
To sad our thought with contemplation
Of past calamities. If any ask
Where lives the widow of the poisoned lord?
Where lies the orphan of a murdered father?
Where lies the father of a butchered son?
Where lives all woe? conduct him to us three;
The downcast ruins of calamity.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sound doleful tunes, a solemn hymn advance,
To close the last act of my vengeance:
And when the subject of your passion's spent,
Sing Mellida is dead, all hearts will relent,
In sad condolement, at that heavy sound,
Never more woe in lesser plot was found.
And, o, if ever time create a muse,
that to th'immortal fame of virgin faith,
Dares once engage his pen to write her death,
Presenting it in some black tragedy.
May it prove gracious, may his style be decked
With freshest blooms of purest elegance;
May it have gentle presence, and the scenes sucked up
By calm attention of choice audience:
And when the closing epilogue appears,
In stead of claps, may it obtain but tears.

div.stage: Cantant.
Exeunt omnes.
Antonij vindictae.
